I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB)  and  the  National  Development  and  Reform 
Commission (NDRC) of the People's Republic of China (PRC) agreed to implement policy and 
advisory technical assistance (TA) for Strengthening Capacity to Address Climate Change for 
Small and Medium-Sized City Development. The Government of the Republic of Korea will 
finance the TA under the Republic of Korea e-Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund. The TA 
concept discussion was initiated with the NDRC in November 2009 and the TA consultation 
mission was fielded 29–30 April 2010. The TA concept paper was jointly developed and was 
approved by ADB on 28 May 2010. The objective, scope, implementation arrangements, and 
financing plan of the TA are reflected in this paper. The NDRC confirmation on the draft TA 
report was obtained on 21 October 2010. The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 
1.1 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  It is estimated that the PRC’s urban population, which was 575 million (43% of the total 
population) as of 2008, will reach 787 million (55% of the population) by 2020, and 1.038 billion 
(73% of the population) by 2050.2 The trend is projected to continue even when the total 
population hits its projected peak of 1.458 billion in 2030 (at which point it is estimated that 
1 billion  will  live  in  cities).3   New  city  development  is  being triggered by  urban  population 
expansion. Cities with more than 1 million inhabitants will increase from 100 in 2007 to about 
220  by  2025,  while  even  more  small  and  medium-sized  urban  centers  will  emerge  to 
accommodate rural migrants.4 Although city expansion and the emergence of new cities can 
reduce poverty by improving access to urban services for rural migrants and the poor, it will put 
pressure on the environment by increasing greenhouse gas emissions and air, water, and solid 
waste pollution. Constructing additional infrastructure requires massive amounts of cement and 
steel, which is responsible for large indirect greenhouse gas emissions during the production 
and transportation process. To illustrate the impact of rural–urban migration, per capita energy 
consumption in urban areas is considered 3.5 to 4 times higher than in rural areas in the PRC. 
 
3.  The Government of the PRC considers urbanization an opportunity to expand economic 
growth  while  promoting  pollution-free,  resource-efficient,  low-carbon  urban  development  to 
support a harmonious and prosperous society.5 Under the Eleventh Five-Year Plan, 2006–2010, 
the government is committed to protecting the environment by reversing the prevailing trend of 
increasing  energy  consumption  per  gross  domestic  product  (GDP),  as  well  as  decreasing 
environmental pollution in the atmosphere (sulfur dioxide) and in surface water bodies (chemical 
oxygen demand). In November 2009, the State Council announced a national target of reducing 
the intensity of carbon dioxide emissions per unit of GDP from the 2005 level of 40%–45% by 
2020.6 While promoting energy efficiency and a green economy, PRC cities will boost their 
capacities for climate change mitigation. In large cities, notable efforts are under way, such as

Liaoning Province and one of the old industrial areas in the Northeast PRC, has also been 
chosen as a pilot of the Sustainable Cities Program of the United Nations Environment Program 
and the United Nations Centre for Human Settlements. However, a knowledge gap hinders 
efforts in the PRC to promote low-carbon economic growth and develop small and medium-
sized cities, where financial resources and capacities are more limited than in large cities.8 
Since small and medium-sized city development is inevitable and is considered a main driver of 
the PRC economy, it is vital to guide this development in a way that maximizes savings on 
capital investments, while minimizes abatement costs of greenhouse gas reduction. 
 
4.  The TA is consistent with (i) ADB's country partnership strategy (CPS), 2008–2010 for 
the PRC, which lists urban environmental improvement as a component of resource efficiency 
and environmental sustainability—one of the four main pillars of the CPS; (ii) ADB's Strategy 
2020,  emphasizing  climate  change  and  livable  cities  as  the  main  components  of 
environmentally sustainable growth—a core area of operation to achieve ADB's vision and new 
strategic agenda; and (iii) ADB’s Urban Sector Strategy,  which supports greater use of energy-
saving  development,  reduced  use  of  nonrenewable  resources,  and  improved  urban 
management as key elements to achieving sustainable urban development. 9 
 
5.  The scope of the TA is consistent with the PRC's national long-term goal of building a 
harmonious  and  moderately  prosperous  society.  Resource-efficient  urban  development  is 
identified as one of 11 core development areas for national economic and social development 
under the Medium and Long-Term Science and Technology Development Plan, 2006–2020.10 
The  PRC's  National  Climate  Change  Program  (2007)  also  identified  challenges  such  as 
decoupling economic growth (in terms of per capita GDP) and greenhouse gas emissions, and 
seeking innovative and sustainable development for the country. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
6.  The  TA  will  assist  the  government's  effort  to  strengthen  the  capacity  of  small  and 
medium-sized  cities  to  address  climate  change  and  pursue  low-carbon  city  development 
through knowledge sharing. Drawing on national and international experiences—especially from 
the Republic of Korea, Japan, the United States, and European countries—the objective of the 
TA is to design a national low-carbon development strategy and associated policy guidelines for 
small and medium-sized cities in the PRC. This will be implemented by 
 
(i)  reviewing  the  status  of  small  and  medium-sized  city  development  and  the 
environmental challenges they face, and identifying bottlenecks hindering urban 
management;  
(ii)  reviewing and analyzing national and international best policies and practices in 
urban  development  in  terms  of  promoting  (a)  efficient  urban  land  use  and 
transport planning, (b) energy and resource use efficiency in  the residential,

(iv)  drafting a national low-carbon city development strategy and policy guidelines for

(v)  finalizing the national strategy and policy guidelines by consulting with relevant 
agencies and ministries in the PRC, and holding a knowledge-sharing capacity 
building workshop to disseminate TA findings to key stakeholders. 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
7.  The impact of the TA is increased energy efficiency and decreased per GDP carbon 
emission in small and medium-sized cities in the PRC. The impact is fully supported by the TA 
outcome of improved capacity of the PRC government to guide low-carbon small and medium-
sized city development. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
8.  The TA will comprise five outputs with corresponding activities as follows. 
 
(i)  Review of the status of small and medium-sized city development in the 
PRC. The successful delivery of this output will be ensured by implementing a 
detailed baseline review and analysis of the PRC's urbanization trend, national 
policy objectives, and the status of small and medium-sized city development in 
the PRC. This analysis will enable the TA to define several paths to pursue low-
carbon  development  for  cities. 11 The  TA  will  (a)  review  the  PRC's  future 
urbanization trend and define “small and medium-sized city” in the context of the 
PRC; (b) review national, regional, and local policies designed to influence small 
and medium-sized city development; (c) select two or three small and medium-
sized PRC pilot cities to be the focus of critical literature reviews and surveys on 
their low-carbon development challenges.12 The focus of these surveys will be to 
identify cities’ challenges on (a) balanced social and economic development, (b) 
environmental improvement, and (c) reducing greenhouse gas emissions. 
 
(ii)  Summary of national and international best practices. Some PRC cities take 
innovative  approaches  to  urban  land  use  and  transport  planning,  energy 
consumption and resource utilization. Cities in developed countries accumulate 
best practices in urban land use and transport planning, resource utilization, and 
energy use, and many of these best practices are useful models for low-carbon 
city development in the PRC.13 The TA will review national and international 
experiences in low-carbon policy and practices in three areas: (a) efficient urban

land  use  and  transport  planning;  (b)  energy  savings  in  the  residential, 
commercial, and industrial sectors; and (c) resource efficiency in the residential, 
commercial,  and  industrial  sectors.  The  review  will  also  include  ways  to 
implement the identified best policies and practices, identify ways to potentially 
cut  greenhouse  gas  emissions,  and  estimate  the  investment  required  to 
implement each policy and practice. The TA will produce a database of national 
and international best policies and practices on low-carbon small and medium-
sized city development. 
 
(iii)  Knowledge-sharing  analysis.  There  is  no  one-size-fits-all  approach  for 
supporting the development of low-carbon small and medium-sized cities. The 
TA will (a) analyze the applicability of best policies and practices to various PRC 
cities by considering urban trends, climate conditions, city economies, and social 
and cultural characteristics; (b) conduct a detailed analysis of the applicability of 
best policies and practices to the pilot cites; (c) for each pilot city, calculate 
potential  savings  from  reduced  resource  consumption,  energy  use,  and 
greenhouse gas emissions, and estimate the needed financial investment to 
implement those policies and practices; and (d) refine installation requirements of 
best policies and practices through the analysis of pilot cities. 
 
(iv)  National low-carbon city development strategies and policy guidelines. The 
TA will draft simple but concise national low-carbon small and medium-sized city 
development strategies and policy guidelines, in line with other national, regional, 
and local development policies and objectives. These documents will be finalized 
through consultations with relevant agencies and ministries in the PRC.  
 
(v)  Capacity building and dissemination of TA findings. This TA output will be 
implemented through the NDRC–ADB knowledge sharing workshop on domestic 
and  international  best  practices  for  PRC  government  officials.  The  TA  will 
generate knowledge products on  national and international  best policies and 
practices for small and medium-sized city development, and will introduce PRC 
government  officials  to  approaches  to  promoting  low-carbon  city  growth.  TA 
outputs will also be disseminated through a regional knowledge platform for 
sustainable urban development established under ADB TA for Establishing a 
Regional Knowledge Hub for Sustainable Urban Development.14 
 
9.  The potential risks of TA implementation include (i) limited availability of information on 
national best policies and practices from PRC cities, (ii) limited availability of information for pilot 
cities to implement detailed analysis on applicability of best policies and practices, potential 
greenhouse  gas  emission  savings  and  necessary  financial  investment,  and  (iii)  a  lack  of 
willingness  of  local  governments  to  follow  the  national  low-carbon  development  policy 
guidelines.  The  TA  will  mitigate  these  risks  through  careful  selection  of  pilot  cities,  close 
communication  with  the  NDRC  and  pilot  cities,  and  use  of  robust  scientific  approach  to 
supplement the lacking information.

C.  Cost and Financing 
10.  The TA is estimated to cost $625,000 equivalent, of which $500,000 will be financed on 
a  grant  basis  by  the  Republic  of  Korea  e-Asia  and  Knowledge  Partnership  Fund,  and 
administered by ADB. The government will provide $125,000 equivalent in in-kind contributions. 
The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
11.  The  NDRC  will  be  the  executing  agency. In-kind  contributions from the  NDRC  will 
include temporary office accommodation, counterpart staff, research assistance in conducting 
surveys  and  collecting  data,  logistical  support  for  workshops,  and  knowledge  product 
dissemination. 
 
12.  The TA will be implemented over 16 months from February 2011 to June 2012 with a 
draft final report to be submitted within 12 months after mobilization of the consultant. The 
database  of  national  and  international  good  policies  and  practices  on  low-carbon  city 
development, and the national low-carbon small and medium-sized city development strategies 
and policy guidelines, will be completed by January 2012. The capacity building workshop will 
be held by March 2012. The knowledge products are to be finalized and disseminated widely to 
international and national communities by June 2012. 
 
13.  The TA will require four international consultants for a total of 13 person-months and four 
national consultants for a total of 20 person-months. Both international and national consultant 
teams will comprise specialists on environmental policy and management, urban land use and 
transport planning, energy management, and resource management. The consultants will be 
engaged in accordance with ADB's Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended 
from time to time) and all necessary equipment will be procured in accordance with ADB's 
Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time to time). The proceeds of the TA will be 
disbursed in accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as 
amended from time to time). The consultants’ terms of reference are in Appendix 3. The TA will 
engage relevant consultants on an individual basis because, for consultant selection, individual 
experience and qualifications of consultants are the main requirements. The TA requires highly 
qualified  international  and  national  experts  in  the  field  of  urban  environmental  policy  and 
management,  land  use  and  transport  planning,  energy  management,  and  resource 
management. These experts will be required to demonstrate strong experience and familiarity in 
climate change mitigation and policies for cities in the context of the PRC and Asia. Experienced 
and qualified candidates can be best engaged through individual consultant selection, rather 
than through private firms. The NDRC and ADB will coordinate and communicate closely with 
each expert to ensure their collective performance as a team. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
14.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved ADB 
administering technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $500,000 to the Government 
of the People’s Republic of China to be financed on a grant basis by the Republic of Korea e-
Asia and Knowledge Partnership Fund for Strengthening Capacity to Address Climate Change

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Introduction 
 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will address climate change by strengthening the capacity 
of the Government of the People's Republic of China (PRC) to guide low-carbon development of 
small and medium-sized cities. The consultants will work closely with the executing agency—the 
National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC)—and local governments of pilot cities. 
 
B.  International Consultants 
 
2.  Urban  management  specialist/team  leader  (4.0  person-months,  intermittent).  The 
specialist shall have a relevant degree and/or an extensive knowledge and experience in the 
fields of urban management, urban environmental policy, and urban governance. Familiarity 
with resource efficiency (e.g., municipal and industrial waste management); energy savings in 
buildings  and  industries;  and  urban  land  use  and  transport  planning  (i.e.,  compact  city, 
transport-oriented development) in the context of greenhouse gas emission reduction and low-
carbon city growth is preferable. Among other responsibilities, the specialist will  
(i)  prepare  a  detailed  work  plan  for  the  TA  and  ensure  that  the  team's  work 
progresses according to schedule and that outputs are submitted on time and are 
of a quality acceptable to the NDRC and ADB; 
(ii)  liaise and coordinate with the NDRC, local and provincial governments, local 
expert institutions, and agencies involved in the TA; 
(iii)  undertake an extensive literature review on international and national policies on 
urbanization and climate change mitigation and conduct a detailed analysis of the 
status of small and medium-sized city development in the PRC; 
(iv)  discuss with the NDRC and select 2–3 pilot cities and collect information, review, 
and analyze development challenges and bottlenecks of pilot cities to minimize 
greenhouse gas emissions; 
(v)  analyze  and  determine  various  low-carbon  development  paths for  small  and 
medium-sized cities in the PRC; 
(vi)  lead a critical review of best international policies and practices to minimize 
greenhouse gas emissions in cities, including technical, financial, and political 
requirements for implementing those best practices and policies; 
(vii)  compile a list of more than 100 best national and international  policies and 
practices, and develop a database for promoting low-carbon small and medium-
sized city development; 
(viii)  lead an analysis of the feasibility of applying those best policies and practices to 
PRC small and medium-sized cities; 
(ix)  lead a detailed analysis to estimate the potential for reducing greenhouse gas 
emissions in pilot cities, and estimate the financial investment required to apply 
policies and practices to realize those reductions; 
(x)  draft  simple  but  concise  national  low-carbon  small  and  medium-sized  city 
development policy guidelines for PRC; 
(xi)  organize a capacity development workshop for PRC government officials and 
urban practitioners on low-carbon city development and present the TA findings; 
and 
(xii)  produce TA reports and two knowledge products, which are submitted on time 
and are of a quality acceptable to the NDRC and ADB. 
 
3.  Urban land use and transport planning specialist (3.0 person-months, intermittent). 
The international urban land use and transport planning specialist should have a background in

Appendix 3  11 
engineering or science and extensive knowledge of and experience in urban land use and 
transport planning and policy, including relevant international laws, regulations, and incentives. 
Familiarity with transport-oriented development and compact city, smart-growth, and various 
eco-city concepts are preferable. Among other responsibilities, the specialist will 
(i)  undertake a critical literature review and conduct surveys to analyze the status of 
greenhouse gas emissions emanating from land use and urban transport in pilot 
cities, and identify challenges to minimizing greenhouse gas emissions. 
(ii)  identify, in the aspect of urban land use and transport planning, key aspects to 
determine different low-carbon development paths of small and medium-sized 
cities in the PRC; 
(iii)  critically review international best policies and practices on urban land use and 
transport planning to minimize greenhouse gas emissions cities; 
(iv)  critically review international emerging technologies, innovative ideas, policies, 
and strategic planning influencing urban land use and transport planning; 
(v)  compile national and international best policies and practices on urban land use 
and transport planning, including technical, financial, and political requirements 
for implementing those best practices and policies; 
(vi)  identify  technical,  financial,  and  political  requirements  for  implementing  best 
practices and policies on urban land use and transport planning in PRC’s small 
and medium-sized cities; 
(vii)  conduct a detailed analysis of pilot cities to estimate greenhouse gas emission 
reduction  and  financial  investment  required  by  applying  recommended  best 
policies and practices on urban land use and transport planning; 
(viii)  assist the team leader to draft national low-carbon small and medium-sized city 
development policy guidelines, and to prepare high-quality TA reports and two 
knowledge products; and 
(ix)  present the TA findings in the capacity development workshop. 
 
4.  Energy specialist (3.0 person-months, intermittent). The international energy specialist 
should have a strong background in energy-related engineering, with extensive knowledge and 
experience in the field of energy-demand management in an urban environment, including 
knowledge of relevant international laws, regulations, and incentive measures. Among other 
responsibilities, the specialist will 
(i)  analyze  the  status  of  minimizing  greenhouse  gas  emissions  through  energy 
saving measures in pilot cities by conducting surveys and undertaking a critical 
literature review; 
(ii)  identify, in the aspect of energy saving, key aspects to determine different low-
carbon development paths of small and medium-sized cities in the PRC; 
(iii)  critically  review  international  best  policies  and  practices  on  energy-saving 
designed to minimize greenhouse gas emissions in cities; 
(iv)  critically  review  international  emerging  technologies,  innovative  ideas  and 
policies influencing energy saving in cities; 
(v)  compile  national  and  international  best  energy-saving  policies  and  practices, 
including technical, financial, and political requirements for implementing those 
best practices and policies; 
(vi)  identify technical, financial, and political requirements for implementing collected 
best policies and practices related to energy saving in PRC small and medium-

(vii)  conduct a detailed analysis to estimate the potential for reducing greenhouse  
gas emissions in pilot cities, and estimate the financial investment required to 
apply energy-saving policies and practices to realize those reductions;

(viii)  assist the team leader to draft national low-carbon small and medium-sized city 
development policy guidelines and to prepare high-quality TA reports and two 
knowledge products; and 
(ix)  present the TA findings in the capacity development workshop. 
 
5.  Resource  efficiency  specialist  (3.0  person-months,  intermittent).  The  international 
resource efficiency specialist should have a strong urban and/or environmental engineering 
background, with extensive knowledge and experience in solid waste management, industrial 
waste management, sludge treatment, life cycle assessment and the 3R initiatives (i.e., reuse, 
reduce, recycle), including knowledge of relevant international laws, regulations, and incentives. 
Among other responsibilities, the specialist will 
(i)  analyze the status of minimizing greenhouse gas emissions through resource 
efficiency  measures  in  pilot  cities  by  conducting  surveys  and  undertaking  a 
critical literature review; 
(ii)  identify, in the aspect of urban resource efficiency, key aspects to determine 
different low-carbon development paths of small and medium-sized cities in the 
PRC; 
(iii)  critically review international best policies and practices on resource efficiency 
designed to minimize greenhouse gas emissions in cities; 
(iv)  critically  review  international  emerging  technologies,  innovative  ideas  and 
policies influencing resource efficiency in cities; 
(v)  compile  national  and  international  best  policies  and  practices  on  resource 
efficiency,  including  technical,  financial,  and  political  requirements  for 
implementing those best practices and policies; 
(vi)  identify technical, financial, and political requirements for implementing collected 
best policies and practices on resource efficiency small and medium-sized cities 
in the PRC; 
(x)  conduct a detailed analysis to estimate the potential for reducing greenhouse gas 
emissions in pilot cities, and estimate the financial investment required to apply 
resource efficient policies and practices to realize those reductions; 
(vii)  assist the team leader to draft national low-carbon small and medium-sized city 
development policy guidelines and to prepare high-quality TA reports and two 
knowledge products; and 
(viii)  present the TA findings in the capacity development workshop. 
 
C.  National Consultants  
 
6.  Urban management specialist/ deputy team leader (5.0 person-months, intermittent). 
The national urban management specialist should have qualifications and broad experience in 
urban management policy in the PRC. Familiarity with urban environmental policy related to 
resource efficiency, energy savings, and urban land use and transport planning are preferable. 
Among other responsibilities, the specialist will 
(i)  assist the team leader in collecting information about PRC’s national policy on 
small and medium-sized city development and climate change mitigation, and 
conduct a detailed analysis of the current status of city development in the PRC; 
(ii)  collect relevant information to define ‘small and medium cities’ for the PRC; 
(iii)  for  pilot  cities,  undertake  a  critical  literature  review  and  conduct  surveys  to 
analyze  the  urbanization  trend,  urban  development  policies  and  planning 
concepts, and cities’ challenges on (a) balanced socioeconomic development, (b) 
environmental improvement, and (c) reducing greenhouse gas emissions; 
(iv)  undertake  an  extensive  literature  review  and  analysis  on  local  conditions  to 
identify different low-carbon paths of small and medium-sized cities in the PRC;

(v)  lead a critical review of national best policies and practices for low-carbon city 
development and assist the team leader in compiling national and international 
best practices and policies and develop a database for low-carbon small and 
medium-sized city development in the PRC; 
(vi)  identify requirements for implementing the collected best policies and practices, 
and analyze feasibility of applying those best policies and practices to PRC small 
and medium-sized cities; 
(vii)  assist  international  specialist  to  analyze  a  set  of  low-carbon  policies  and 
practices applicable to the pilot cities, calculate potential greenhouse gas savings; 
and estimate the financial investment required to realize those savings; 
(viii)  assist the team leader in producing high-quality TA reports and two knowledge 
products; and 
(ix)  assist the team leader in organizing the capacity development workshop. 
 
7.  Urban land use and transport planning specialist (5.0 person-months, intermittent). 
The national urban land use and transport planning specialist should have qualifications and 
broad experience in urban planning, including land use planning and transport planning in the 
PRC. Familiarity with compact city, smart growth and eco-city concepts and climate change 
mitigation measures in cities is preferable. Among other responsibilities, the specialist will 
(i)  undertake an extensive literature review and analysis on urban land use and 
transport planning conditions to identify different low-carbon paths of small and 
medium-sized cities in the PRC; 
(ii)  collect  data  on  the  status  of  minimizing  land-use-related  greenhouse  gas 
emissions and identify challenges to urban transport planning in pilot cities; 
(iii)  collect information on national best policies and practices on urban land use and 
transport  planning  in  PRC  cities  and  assist  the  international  specialist  in 
compiling national and international best practice and policy databases; 
(iv)  identify technical, financial, and political requirements for implementing urban 
land  use  and  transport  planning  best  policies  and  practices,  and  analyze 
feasibility  of  applying  those  best  policies  and  practices  to  PRC  small  and 
medium-sized cities; 
(v)  assist international specialist to conduct a detailed analysis for pilot cities on the 
feasibility of implementing the collected best policies and practices on urban land 
use and transport planning; 
(vi)  provide inputs to team leader and international specialist to draft national low-
carbon city development strategies and policy guidelines; 
(vii)  assist the team leader to produce high-quality TA reports and two knowledge 
products; and 
(viii)  assist the team leader in organizing the capacity development workshop. 
 
8.  Energy specialist (5.0 person-months, intermittent). The national energy specialist will 
have relevant qualifications and experience on analyzing urban energy supply and demand, 
energy saving technology, and energy management in the PRC. Previous work experience in 
greenhouse gas inventory analysis and/or climate change impacts on energy use and supply is 
preferable. Among other responsibilities, the specialist will 
(i)  undertake  an  extensive  literature  review  and  analysis  on  energy  saving 
conditions to identify different low-carbon paths of small and medium-sized cities

(iii)  collect information on national best policies and practices on energy saving in 
PRC  cities  and  assist  the  international  specialist  in  compiling  national  and

(iv)  identify technical, financial, and political criteria for implementing best practices

9.  Resource  efficiency  specialist  (5.0  person-months,  intermittent).  The  national 
resource efficiency specialist will have qualifications and experience in solid and industrial waste 
management  and  in  3R  (i.e.,  reuse,  reduce,  recycle)  policies  and  initiatives  in  the  PRC. 
Familiarity with the circular economy policy and its implementation is preferable. Among other 
responsibilities, the specialist will 
(i)  undertake an extensive literature review and analysis on resource utilization and 
waste management conditions to identify different low-carbon paths of small and 
medium-sized cities in the PRC; 
(ii)  collect data on the status of minimizing greenhouse gas emissions through more 
efficient resource use in pilot cities; 
(iii)  collect information on national best policies and practices on resource efficiency 
in PRC cities and assist the international specialist in compiling national and 
international best practice and policy databases; 
(iv)  identify  technical,  financial,  and  political  requirements  for  implementing  best 
practices and policies related to resource efficiency, and analyze feasibility of 
applying those best policies and practices to PRC small and medium-sized cities; 
(v)  assist international consultant to conduct a detailed analysis for pilot cities on the 
feasibility of implementing the collected best policies and practices related to 
resource efficiency; 
(vi)  provide inputs to the team leader and international specialist to draft national low-
carbon city development strategies and policy guidelines; 
(vii)  assist the team leader to produce high-quality TA reports and two knowledge 
products; and 
(viii)  assist the team leader in organizing the capacity development workshop. 
 
D.  Reporting 
 
10.  The consultants will submit the following reports and outputs: (i) an inception report 
within 4 weeks from the start of the TA; (ii) an interim report submitted 6 months after the TA 
starts; (iii) a draft outline of knowledge products by the end of month 8, first draft by the end of 
month 13, and final draft by the end of month 15; (iv) a database of national and international 
good policies and practices on low-carbon city development by the end of month 10; (v) a draft 
final report, to be submitted within 12 months of the end of the TA, containing the results from all 
analyses and an outline of a national strategy and policy guidelines for low-carbon small and 
medium-sized city development in the PRC; and (vi) a final report submitted 1 month after 
receiving comments on the draft final report from the NDRC and ADB. All reports and outputs 
will  be  in  English  but  draft  final  report,  final  report  and  two  knowledge  products  shall  be 
translated into Chinese.
